fields.description:
The subversion apache authorization module {{mod_authz_svn}} has a special check that allows the user to specify which parts of their repository should have anonymous access.

It works like this: If the apache config contains both the {{Satisfy Any}} and {{Require valid-user}} directives, then anonymous access is granted to the "*" user in the authorization file (see http://svnbook.red-bean.com/nightly/en/svn.serverconfig.pathbasedauthz.html).

The CrowdAuth and CrowdAuthz modules don't currently support this behavior.

(cf CWDSUP-1349)
fields.summary: Apache module doesn't support mixed anonymous/required authentication as well as mod_authz_svn

fields.description:
Mixed access to a Subversion repository on directory level permissions doesn't work.

I have installed the Apache Connector and it works fine.
I was also able to install Apache::CrowdAuthz for doing the authorization.
It works all fine if you do only restricted access with "require valid-user" in the configuration. 

But what it needs is
- anonymous access to some directories 
- restricted access to some directories based on group membership 

Subversion configures that normally by using: "Satisfy Any" AND "Require valid-user" (see Example 6.3. A sample configuration for mixed authenticated/anonymous access )



Example Config File: httpd.conf
<Location / >
   AuthName crowd
   AuthType Basic
   PerlAuthenHandler Apache::CrowdAuth
   PerlSetVar CrowdAppName subversion
   PerlSetVar CrowdAppPassword pwd
   PerlSetVar CrowdSOAPURL http://localhost:8095/crowd/services/SecurityServer
   PerlSetVar CrowdCacheEnabled off
   PerlSetVar CrowdCacheLocation tmp/CrowdAuth
   PerlSetVar CrowdCacheExpiry 300

   PerlAuthzHandler Apache::CrowdAuthz
   PerlSetVar CrowdAuthzSVNAccessFile C:/Programs/Apache2.0/conf/dav_svn.authz

   DAV svn
   SVNPath D:\Data\SubversionRepositories\herasaf
   SVNPathAuthz on
   
   Satisfy Any
   Require valid-user
</Location>

Example Config File dav_svn.authz:

Members of the subversion-comitters group can 
read to the education folder 
[/education]
@subversion-comitters = r
* = 

Members of the subversion-comitters group can 
read to the research folder 
[/research]
@subversion-comitters = r
* = 

Everyone has read access to the repository 
(unless modified below). 
[/]
* = r 


The Problem is that it always permits read access to anonymous users and doesn't ask for authentication when accessing one of the restricted folders.
fields.summary: mixed (authenticated/anonymous) access control doesn't work

fields.description:
I'm surprised this hasn't been requested before. Basically, it'd be nice for custom RemoteDirectory implementations to provide some metadata about how they could be configured and then a UI automatically generated from this metadata.

For example, I'd like to be able to specify a JNDI name to get access to a DataSource. Sure, I can use system properties or hard-code the configuration in, but wouldn't it be nicer if I could do this through the admin UI?

Prioritization as Minor because there are obvious workarounds.
fields.summary: Allow custom directories to be configured

fields.description:
Since users are automatically added to Domain Users, it would be nice if this group could be used by Crowdified applications like JIRA or Confluence.

(For clarity, the issue is not specific to "Domain Users". The issue is that a user's membership of their "primary group" is not recognised by Crowd. In most cases, this will be "Domain Users", as this is the default primary group.)

Articles of Interest:

  http://blogs.msdn.com/alextch/archive/2007/06/18/sample-java-application-that-retrieves-group-membership-of-an-active-directory-user-account.aspx

  http://forums.sun.com/thread.jspa?threadID=581444&tstart=150
fields.summary: Provide support for Active Directory Primary group memberships (eg. Domain Users, Domain Admins)

{panel:title=Atlassian Update - 8 June 2020|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
Hello everyone,

We have recently reviewed this issue and the overall interest in the problem. As the issue hasn't collect votes, watchers, comments, or support cases from many customers during its lifetime, it's very low on our priority list, and will not be fixed in the foreseeable future. That's why we've decided to resolve it as *Timed Out*.

Although we're aware the issue is still important to those of you who were involved in the conversations around it, we want to be clear in managing your expectations. The Crowd team is focusing on issues that have broad impact and high value, reflected by the number of comments, votes, support cases, and customers interested. Please consult the [Atlassian Bugfix Policy|https://confluence.atlassian.com/support/atlassian-server-bug-fix-policy-201294573.html] for more details.

We understand how disappointing this decision may be, but we hope you'll appreciate our transparent approach and communication.

Atlassian will continue to watch this issue for further updates, so please feel free to share your thoughts in the comments.

Thank you,

Crowd Team

fields.description:
At present, Crowd-integrated clients such as JIRA or Confluence, will not see changes made in Crowd until their Crowd cache expires.  

This default value is set to 1 hour (3600 seconds) in the application's WEB-INF/classes/crowd-ehcache.xml file.  User can reduce these values to cause faster updates (e.g. 300 seconds).  However, this may cause serious performance degradation (especially in JIRA).

Changes made to users and groups via the Crowd client application (e.g. JIRA) will be immediately available in the application in Crowd.

In the future, we need to have Crowd send event notifications to these client applications for smaller cache updates.  This will not only resolve this problem but help with Crowdified application performance as well.
fields.summary: Provide event-driven updates for Crowd-integrated applications.

fields.description:
The XWork ParametersInterceptor is a security nightmare as it gives user input (submitted form parameters) unfettered access to getter/setter methods on action objects. In addition, the interceptor has been shown in the past to be vulnerable to Unicode attacks.
Rather than fight a constant (and often losing) battle to prevent actions from leaking important classes, we should rewrite the parameters interceptor to obey the following rules:
*Parameter keys will be ignored if they contain characters other than A-Za-z0-9, periods and square brackets.
*Where a parameter is reading a property using dot notation (i.e. ?searchBean.query=blah), the getter method for that property must have the @ActionSafeParameter annotation
fields.summary: Make XWork ParametersInterceptor safe from parameter injection attacks

fields.description:
This Feature request is one of the solution that can be implemented for the goal of implementing the feature mentioned at [CWD-5145 - Only users who have access to applications connected to Crowd should be synchronized from Crowd to those applications|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CWD-5145]

When a directory is associated with an application in Crowd, all users and groups returned by the scope of the directory configuration are displayed in client applications.  We should provide the ability to filter users/groups for client apps based on the ability to authenticate in the client app.

- Setup an LDAP server with users, only some are added to a group.
- Add the LDAP directory to crowd
- Login to crowd and under Applications, click on "Add Application". 
- In the directories tab, remove the internal directory and add the LDAP directory (allow all to authenticate = false)
- In the groups tab, add the LDAP group
- Go to the users tab.

*Expected:* Only users from the LDAP group to be present, the rest have no permission to authenticate and are not part of the valid groups.
*Actual:* All users from the directory are present.

This is a design decision in Crowd, as most customers want all users and groups to be present, regardless of the ability to authenticate. We may consider providing a toggle for this behaviour in the future, but it's not on a roadmap at present.
fields.summary: Provide flag to filter users/groups to client applications based on application's permission to authenticate.

fields.description:
Currently, displaying a list of group members (eg. "show all members of jira-developers" in the JIRA user browser) can be extremely slow in Crowd. This is because Crowd first fetches the group DN to fetch the user list, then for each member, does a LDAP query to fetch their details. If there are 20,000 users, that is 20,001 LDAP queries.

Performance would be much better if Crowd could issue an LDAP query saying "Give me details for all users in group X", and get back all results in one query.

Till recently this has not been possible (except in AD, I believe), but OpenLDAP 2.4+ has a feature called [Reverse Group Membership Maintenance|http://www.openldap.org/doc/admin24/overlays.html#Reverse Group Membership Maintenance], also known as the "memberof" attribute.  This automatically populated/updated attribute lists the groups that a user is a member of.  Crowd could use this to list group members, ie. "Give me all entries where memberOf=jira-users".
fields.summary: Speed up OpenLDAP user listings using memberOf group membership attribute

fields.description: Something has changed that forces users to enter the exact casing of the LDAP username.  In the past, this was not required.
fields.summary: Username case matters in JIRA if you're using Crowd 1.4.x or 1.5, it didn't used to in Crowd 1.3.x

fields.description:
On startup the following error is displayed:
{noformat}
Creating a new instance of CacheManager using the diskStorePath "/tmp" which is already used by an existing CacheManager.
The source of the configuration was classpath.
The diskStore path for this CacheManager will be set to /tmp/ehcache_auto_created_1221103809809.
To avoid this warning consider using the CacheManager factory methods to create a singleton CacheManager
or specifying a separate ehcache configuration (ehcache.xml) for each CacheManager instance.
{noformat}

This is caused by *two* caching managers being used by the Crowd Console.

and also:
{noformat}
2008-09-11 13:30:09,833 main WARN [org.hibernate.cache.EhCacheProvider] 
Could not find configuration [com.atlassian.crowd.model.property.Property]; using defaults.
{noformat}
fields.summary: On startup Crowd displays an EHCache error about duplicate disk store paths & no configuration for Property
Review the JAR's filename and path in documentation page

fields.description:
Reproduce bug:
# RemotePrincipal created without givenName attribute via Crowd Console in an LDAP directory
# Attribute givenName is later added via the Crowd Console

The "givenName" attribute is not added to the principal even though it is a supported/mapped LDAP attribute.

This will also affect methods on the SecurityServerClient such as updatePrincipalAttribute/removeAttributeFromPrincipal, and in turn affects integration with applications that first create an almost blank user and then populate the user's properties (eg. creating users via Confluence).
fields.summary: Updating a RemotePrincipal does not add new attributes to LDAP

fields.description: Restored a 1.4 XML backup and could no longer get to Google Apps.  Can't add the Google Apps application either.
fields.summary: Restoring XML backup from pre-Crowd 1.5 version removes Google Apps, requires restart

fields.description:
I am trying to screenscrape a list of group members from the /console/secure/group/viewmembers.action page. Unfortunately HTML Tidy dies while parsing, because of the use of a fictional element: {code:xml}
  • Search Groups
  • Add Group
  • Remove Group
{code} Could we replace this with a div?
fields.summary: Non-HTML <content> element in output

fields.description: Full name searches behave correctly for internal directories but not for LDAP ones.
fields.summary: Full name searches return all users if the underlying Crowd directory is LDAP-based

fields.description: Due to a little subversion snafu, we're missing the defaultCache in the Crowd client/conf/crowd-ehcache.xml file.
fields.summary: crowd-ehcache.xml in Crowd's client directory does not contain defaultCache value

fields.description: processMembers will return all groups in the specified directory twice.  Once for groups and once for roles.  This information is not cached and if a directory contains thousands of groups this can be expensive.  Add VPN connectivity between Crowd and the directory and it gets ugly.
fields.summary: ViewPrincipal's processMemberships is a very expensive call

fields.description:
If the javax mail JAR is missing from the application server, Spring will cause an out of memory error when trying to log the BeanCreationException.

We should have a dependency checker on the BootstrapListener that checks the required dependencies (which we do not include with the crowd-web-app) are present on the classpath. If they are not, a useful log message should be output and a Johnson event fired.
fields.summary: Crowd dependency check on startup

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian Update – 18th March 2019|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#ebf2f9|titleBGColor=#ebf2f9|bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi,

I wanted to let you know that we have released cross-domain Single Sign-On in [Crowd Data Center 3.4|https://confluence.atlassian.com/crowd/crowd-3-4-release-notes-966041084.html] 

You can download Crowd Data Center from here: https://www.atlassian.com/software/crowd/download/data-center

Please note that in order to use cross-domain Single Sign-On in Crowd you will need Crowd Data Center license.

You can create your evaluation license for Crowd Data Center here https://my.atlassian.com/license/evaluation

If you need any assistance with the Crowd Data Center installation you can follow our Getting started guide https://confluence.atlassian.com/crowd/installing-crowd-data-center-935369773.html

We hope that you will enjoy it as much as we do!

Please reply directly to my email to share your feedback or just add your comments in this ticket. We'd love to hear your thoughts!

Best regards,

Marek Radochonski
Senior Product Manager, Crowd
mradochonski@atlassian.com
 
{panel}

Currently we require applications to share a common domain/subdomain to achieve SSO.

Crowd could use an authentication mechanism that does not depend on cookies on a single domain for authentication. This will allow applications to reside on completely different domains (eg. jira.com and confluence.com could be SSO'd with crowd.com).

The solution would heavily rely on redirects to move the user-agent between domains to set the appropriate cookies during logins/logouts.
fields.summary: Cross-domain Single Sign-On

fields.description:
In the Google Apps connector in Crowd 1.5:
* When you sign out of Google Apps, you will also be signed out of Crowd and all Crowd-connected applications. This is the usual SSO behaviour.
* But when you sign out of Crowd, you will remain logged in to Google Apps even though you will be logged out of other Crowd-connected applications. (Reason: Google does not rely on a cookie, so there is no easy way for Crowd to tell Google you have signed out.)

It would be nice if Crowd could support single sign-out of Google Apps.
fields.summary: Google Apps connector should support single sign-out

fields.description:
I am trying to hook an application (Bamboo) up to Crowd. If an application hasn't been configured yet in Crowd, I get the error:

2008-09-02 13:00:40,324 ERROR [btpool0-1] [DefaultUserAccessor] Error in getUser():Invalid application client. The application.name or application.password in your <CROWD DIRECTORY>/crowd-webapp/WEB-INF/classes/crowd.properties file does not match the Crowd database.  For more information please visit http://confluence.atlassian.com/x/FwDHBQ.

This is very confusing, because it assumes the client is the Crowd console, whereas I am setting up Bamboo. I don't have a crowd-webapp/WEB-INF/classes/crowd.properties. Following the suggested URL just adds to the confusion, as it starts to talk about SQL to reset passwords in the Crowd database.
fields.summary: Misleading error message when Crowd application is not set up

fields.description:
Now that we're approaching the release of 1.5, the help links in 1.4 should be redirected to the CROWD014 space.

Please update the .htaccess file to redirect the help calls from Crowd 1.4 to the CROWD014 space, and to send help calls from Crowd 1.5 to the CROWD space.
fields.summary: Configure redirection of context-sensitive online help links for existing 1.4 release
Add mail server test option to send test e-mail from mail setup or admin screen

fields.description:
Document the Plugin Framework 2.0 which is shipped with Crowd 1.5.
* Add the documentation to the Development Hub at http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Crowd+Development+Hub
Split the Dev Hub into two sections, one for the plugins and one for the API.
* Explain that the new Google Apps connector is implemented as a plugin and uses the new framework --- can be used as an example of how to write a plugin.
* Explain the new "application type" = "plugin application".
* Plugin Framework Is backwards compatible with old plugins. 
* The framework is experiemental. We are using it. You can use it too — we'd be delighted to have your feedback. We will be polishing the framework and working on the documentation at the same time
* Refer to the plugin-specific directories, already documented in "Important Directories and Files" (currently in a temp doc at http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Copy+of+Important+Directories+and+Files
* Refer to the generic Plugin Framework docs currently under development at 
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/PLUGINFRAMEWORK/Plugin+Framework+Documentation
and at
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/ATLAS/Plugin+Development+Platform

Tech writer will set up the structure of the pages in the Crowd Dev Hub. Then a developer can fill in the details.
fields.summary: Document the new Plugin Framework
Need to fix how license screen handles current users v. license's number of users
Please update the help-paths.properties file for Crowd 1.5

fields.description:
In order to provide more information during application/directory configuration to ensure admins do not exceed their license count, I would like to add the following:

1.  A member count on the Groups UI.
2.  Number of users on the Application UI.  This might be a bit tricky since a user is only counted once against a license even though they have multiple application access.
fields.summary: Provide better license count information in Admin UI

fields.description:
We need to provide newer versions of Crowd 1.4 PDF, XML and HTML docs, because:
* Crowd 1.4.1 and Crowd 1.4.4 contained new features.
* Docs have undergone a fair bit of improvement since 1.4.0
fields.summary: Create PDF, HTML and XML versions of the Crowd 1.4 docs

fields.description:
Provide ability to search group for members with GROUP_NAME, GROUP_DIRECTORYID, SEARCH_INDEX_START and SEARCH_MAX_RESULTS.  Optional restrictions might include PRINCIPAL_NAME and PRINCIPAL_EMAIL.

This will allow paging for groups with large memberships.
fields.summary: Add searchMembers for remote API

fields.description: Discription
fields.summary: Show Task

fields.description: With a license for 25 users, and 25 users registered in crowd, a user who is not supposed to be accessing the system attempts to login to a client application.  This user is then added to the system, crowd exceeds it's licensing limit, and stops working, causing an outage for all crowd driven systems.  If a user (non-admin) action is going to cause the entire system to come down, it shouldn't be allowed.
fields.summary: Delegated directory adds users automatically even when that will exceed the license limits.
Delegated directory with "Add Users" permission disabled still automatically adds users upon authentication.

fields.description:
At present, if an Active Directory uses range retrieval on group membership,

  http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/aa367017(VS.85).aspx

the default AD configuration in Crowd will not return group members when using the default group member attribute of "member."  Instead, to retrieve group members a group member attribute like the following must be used (range may vary):

{noformat}
member;range=0-1499
{noformat}
 
Unfortunately, any groups that do not use range retrieval will not display members if the above attribute is used.
fields.summary: Support Active Directory Range Retrieval Functionality for Group Memberships

fields.description: We shouldn't need to fetch group members until admin clicks the Members tab.  Right now, Crowd retrieves members every time the admin clicks View or toggles between Members and Details tabs for the group.  This is really expensive.
fields.summary: Fine-tune performance of viewing groups in Crowd.

fields.description:
On the licensing page we have a nice message:

  Your commercial Crowd support and updates are available until Sunday, 21 Sep 2008

However on the crowd/console startup page you see this:

   Your license will expire on 26 Aug 2008, you have 25 days left. 

First we need to fix the date because it appears to be using today's rather than the license date.  Next can we make this friendly like the first message and add a link to http://my.atlassian.com for renewal?
fields.summary: Make the license expiration notice less scary

fields.description:
Crowd will aggressively attempt to cache all groups on an initial login (in the Crowd application or any acegi integrated apps that use caching managers).  

This is extremely expensive since the ObjectTranslator's process groups must convert every RemoteGroup into a SOAPGroup.  In one issue this averaged 30ms per group and with 1600 groups that comes to 48 seconds.

Perhaps we can look at caching only those groups that are associated with the directory's group permissions of the application?
fields.summary: Aggressive caching in CachingGroupManager causes performance problems

fields.description: The User Console counts against a customer's license count.  Perhaps splitting user console and admin console into separate apps?
fields.summary: Provide way to specify groups for Crowd User Console without providing Admin Console access

fields.description: Tested with the demo app on Browse Groups and did contain members.
fields.summary: Setting SearchContext.GROUP_POPULATE_MEMBERSHIPS to "none" still retrieves group memberships.

fields.description:
After CWD-180 is fixed, it seems Crowd+OpenLDAP will create groups with a blank uniqueMember (position 1) in it to satisfy the schema. However, subsequently, if you add an user to the group, it will create another uniqueMember instead of writing to the first blank one. So the end result is for a group with only one valid user, there will be two counts of uniqueMember in it.

This is causing problem on scripts that's expecting a value on the first uniqueMember, and affecting the total count as well. All in all, Crowd doesn't seem to have enough checks to ensure the integrity of the LDAP database, e.g. CWD-1184.

Thanks,
fields.summary: Crowd adds a blank user when creating a new group, which it does not overwrite when adding the first user to the group

fields.description:
Currently, importing large sets of data requires a lot of memory as the collection of data being imported is loaded up to memory before being purged to the database. In order to improve memory efficiency, we need to perform the import in "chunks" such that we read a chunk from the input and write a chunk out to the database. The writing process already supports purging in "chunks" via JDBC batch processing. The input process will need to read in chunks in various ways:
- XML import: use event-based XML processing
- CSV import: read data as a stream
- JDBC import: read pages of data
fields.summary: Improving memory usage when importing large datasets

fields.description: Review and benchmark XML backup speeds for a range of datasets.
fields.summary: Improve XML export speed

fields.description:
To reproduce:
-Log into Crowd
-Go to administration -> logging & profiling
-Turn profiling on by clicking button
-Message should read ' Profiling is currently ON'
-Click Update Logging button (you don't actually need to change any of the logging levels)
-Profiling message should now say ' Profiling is currently OFF'
-Click the link for logging & profiling, page should reload and profiling message goes back to ' Profiling is currently ON'
fields.summary: Crowd profiling label always displays 'off' after logging levels are updated

fields.description:
While Crowd does display nested groups properly, nested groups is not utilized server-side for application permissioning.  

Example:

1.  AD directory with parent group crowd-administrators and child group ldap-administrators.
2.  User A is a member of ldap-administrators.
3.  The crowd application (in Crowd) uses the AD directory with Allow All to Authenticate set to false.  It permits the group crowd-administrators to authenticate.
4.  User A logs in but only receives the user console, not the admin console.

For consistency, we need to permit ldap-administrators the same privs as crowd-administrators.
fields.summary: Crowd server-side support for nested group behavior.

fields.description:
Repro Steps:
# Setup an AD directory and an OpenLDAP directory within crowd
# Make an application that includes both of them
# Create a group in AD called "group-a"
# Create a user in that group called "ad-user"
# Create a group in OpenLDAP called "group-a"
# Create a group in OpenLDAP called "group-b"
# Make "group-a" a member of "group-b"
# Log into application, using "ad-user"
# Look at your groups

Expected:
* To only be in "group-a"

Action
* To be in "group-a" and "group-b"
fields.summary: Recursive Group Bug across directories

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian Update - 8 June 2020|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
Hello everyone,

We have recently reviewed this issue and the overall interest in the problem. As the issue hasn't collect votes, watchers, comments, or support cases from many customers during its lifetime, it's very low on our priority list, and will not be fixed in the foreseeable future. That's why we've decided to resolve it as *Timed Out*.

Although we're aware the issue is still important to those of you who were involved in the conversations around it, we want to be clear in managing your expectations. The Crowd team is focusing on issues that have broad impact and high value, reflected by the number of comments, votes, support cases, and customers interested. Please consult the [Atlassian Bugfix Policy|https://confluence.atlassian.com/support/atlassian-server-bug-fix-policy-201294573.html] for more details.

We understand how disappointing this decision may be, but we hope you'll appreciate our transparent approach and communication.

Atlassian will continue to watch this issue for further updates, so please feel free to share your thoughts in the comments.

Thank you,

Crowd Team
{panel}
 
Since the LDAP spec requires that a group has members, we need to add an empty member if we are removing the last member of a group.
fields.summary: When removing OpenLDAP users from Crowd, removing group memberships may require the addition on an empty user

fields.description:
At present, Crowd will only work with Resin versions 3.0.23 - 3.0.26.  Something has changed in Resin 3.1.x and 3.2 that causes the remote_address value to be nulled out.  

User authenticates.
Authentication is successful.
Crowd attempts to redirect to start page.
Token is checked again but the remote_address value is nulled out causing a redirect to the login page.

We have tried enforcing the xerces XML parser with no change.  This requires more investigation with the dev team.
fields.summary: Provide support for versions of Resin newer than 3.0.26

fields.description: Perhaps indicate they are not a direct member?
fields.summary: Hide Remove link from groups for which user is not a direct member.

fields.description:
When updating user details in JIRA (that is, full name and email), the change isn't reflected until the cache is refreshed.

A quick debug showed that the cause of this problem is that CrowdPropertySet.setString() is not replacing the email and username attributes, but is appending them to the end of the array.  This still works in Crowd probably because it iterates through the array and sets the values in a map or something, so the last value is used.  Meanwhile in JIRA, only the first value in the array is used, so the changes aren't reflected until the cache is expired.
fields.summary: OS User fullname and email updates are not reflected in cache

fields.description:
If an admin specifies a password regex for a Crowd internal directory, users will receive the following error if the new password does not meet the regex qualifier:

  You do not have permission to change your password.

We need to provide clearer errors to help users change passwords successfully.  Perhaps adding one more field to the directory to allow admins to provide their own message if regex is not met?
fields.summary: Need to provide clearer user console messages for changing password
Provide SSL (via XFire) support for Crowd-integrated client applications without the need for a proxy server.

fields.description:
To replicate:

Parent Group: jira-users
Child Group of jira-users: jira-nested-group

User donna is a member of jira-nested-group.

Donna cannot login because the only group that has the JIRA Users global permission (Admin -> Global Settings -> Global Permissions) is the jira-users group.
fields.summary: Nested groups do not work with JIRA Global Permissions

fields.description:
We should not allow Crowd admins to be able to:
- delete themselves
- remove themselves from the admin group
- delete the admin group from the directory they belong in
- delete the directory they belong to

This should help reduce the possibility of admins locking themselves out of Crowd.
fields.summary: Do not allow actions that will lock out admin access
